question: What was the duration of the second scheduled electrical maintenance outage for Béluga and Narval compute nodes in June 2025?
answer: The outage for Béluga and Narval compute nodes, as part of a second scheduled electrical maintenance, ran from 12:00 p.m. (noon EDT) on June 13 until 12:00 p.m. (noon EDT) on June 16, 2025, lasting 3 days.

question: Which systems were affected by the June 13-16, 2025 electrical maintenance, and which were not?
answer: The Béluga and Narval compute nodes, along with Juno Cloud instances in the non-High Availability zone, were shut down. However, Béluga cloud instances and Juno cloud instances in the High Availability zone were not affected. Béluga and Narval storage remained accessible.

question: Were user jobs affected during the June 13-16, 2025 outage?
answer: Jobs scheduled to finish after 12:00 p.m. on June 13 remained queued until the clusters returned to service.

question: Was the June 13-16, 2025 outage related to any other maintenance window?
answer: Yes, this June 13–16 window was in addition to the previously announced outage from June 6 to June 10, 2025.

question: When did the scheduled electrical maintenance for Béluga, Narval, and Juno (non-HA) occur in early June 2025?
answer: The scheduled electrical maintenance required the shutdown of Béluga and Narval compute nodes from 9:00 a.m. (EDT) on June 6 until 12:00 p.m. (noon) on June 10, 2025.

question: What happened to jobs scheduled to finish after 9:00 a.m. on June 6, 2025?
answer: Jobs scheduled to finish after 9:00 a.m. on June 6 remained queued until the clusters were back online.

question: Were cloud instances affected during the June 6-10, 2025 outage?
answer: Cloud instances in the Juno Cloud (non-High Availability zone) were shut down. Cloud instances on Béluga Cloud and in the Juno Cloud HA zone experienced short access outages.

question: How did the June 6-10, 2025 maintenance affect storage systems on Béluga and Narval?
answer: Storage systems on Béluga and Narval remained accessible via Globus and login nodes but saw intermittent disruptions due to the work.

question: What were the dates and times for the electrical maintenance outage affecting Béluga, Narval, and Juno (non-HA) in late April/early May 2025?
answer: Scheduled electrical maintenance required the shutdown of Béluga and Narval compute nodes from 12:00 PM (EDT) on April 30 until 12:00 PM (EDT) on May 1, 2025.

question: Which specific Juno Cloud instances were affected during the April 30 - May 1, 2025 outage?
answer: Cloud instances in the Juno cloud (non-high availability zone) were shut down during this time. Juno cloud instances in the high availability zone were not affected.

question: Did the April 30 - May 1, 2025 outage impact Béluga Cloud instances or Béluga and Narval storage?
answer: These interruptions did not affect Béluga cloud instances. Béluga and Narval storage remained accessible through Globus and the login nodes of each cluster.

question: Why was the Cedar cluster completely unavailable from March 31 to April 2, 2025?
answer: A planned outage was required to perform power modifications as part of the preparations for bringing new equipment online.

question: What was the impact on users attempting to run jobs or log in to the Cedar cluster during the March 31 - April 2, 2025 outage?
answer: Users were not able to log in or run jobs on the cluster. Any jobs running at the time of the outage were terminated and had to be re-submitted once the cluster came back online.

question: Did Cedar Cloud remain operational during the March 31 - April 2, 2025 Cedar cluster outage?
answer: Yes, Cedar Cloud remained operational during this period.

question: When was the Graham cluster originally scheduled for a complete data center shutdown due to renovations, and was it extended?
answer: The Graham cluster was originally scheduled for a complete data center shutdown from December 7, 2024, to January 3, 2025. This outage was extended to February 24, 2025.

question: What services were unavailable on the Graham cluster during its extended outage from December 2024 to February 2025?
answer: During this time, all Graham cluster services, storage, and cloud services were entirely unavailable.

question: What was the reason for the temporary reduction in capacity for Béluga and Narval from January 13 to February 14, 2025?
answer: Performance and stability tests on Rorqual required the shutdown of all Béluga compute nodes and about half of Narval compute nodes.

question: What was the initial impact on Béluga and Narval compute nodes during the temporary reduction starting January 13, 2025?
answer: All Béluga compute nodes were shut down, and approximately 50% of Narval compute nodes (from each category: CPU, GPU, and large memory) were shut down.

question: Were login nodes and data access affected during the Béluga and Narval temporary reduction in early 2025?
answer: Login nodes and data access remained operational.

question: How was Béluga Storage handled during the temporary reduction for Béluga and Narval?
answer: During the shutdown time, Béluga Storage (/lustre01, /lustre02, /lustre03, /lustre04 of Beluga) was mounted to Narval.

question: What was the update regarding Narval's compute capacity and the expected return to 100% capacity for Béluga and Narval, as of January 30, 2025?
answer: As of January 30, 2025, Narval's compute capacity was at 100% until February 6, then again at 30% for the last Rorqual tests. Béluga and Narval were expected to be back to 100% capacity on February 14.
